headline: As Russia Chokes Ukraine’s Grain Exports, Romania Tries to Fill In
snippet: With famine threatening millions, Europe is intent on finding alternatives to one of world’s biggest food exporters, whose landlocked crop is stranded by war.

headline: Truck Makers Face a Tech Dilemma: Batteries or Hydrogen?
snippet: Under pressure to cut emissions, truck manufacturers are choosing between batteries and hydrogen fuel cells. Wagering incorrectly could cost them billions of dollars.

headline: Tesla Autopilot and Other Driver-Assist Systems Linked to Hundreds of Crashes
snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration released data on 10 months of crashes involving cars with automated components. A few were fatal.

headline: Even in Flush Tennis, Equal Pay is a Struggle
snippet: The top players make tens of millions. Others have trouble breaking even.

headline: A Rise in Murders Upends a Sense of Progress in Brooklyn’s East Flatbush
snippet: The killing of a 12-year-old boy in the neighborhood captured how a spike in shootings during the pandemic is complicating recovery in less affluent neighborhoods.

headline: As Biden Pleads for More Covid Aid, States Are Awash in Federal Dollars
snippet: States pushed back on a plan to take back some of their stimulus money to fund President Biden’s emergency spending request. Now Congress is trying to find other ways to offset the cost.

headline: Hyundai’s Ioniq 5 Nods to Past While Pushing Toward E.V. Future
snippet: For now, supply may be constrained, but Hyundai is putting a big bet on building electrics for the American market.

snippet: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.

headline: Africa’s First Covid-19 Vaccine Factory Hasn’t Received a Single Order
snippet: Aspen Pharmacare, in South Africa, was licensed to produce the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. It was hailed as an answer to Africa’s struggle to get access to vaccines.

headline: Emergent Hid Evidence of Covid Vaccine Problems at Plant, Report Says
snippet: The report sheds new light on executives’ worries about deficiencies in the company’s quality control systems at its troubled Baltimore plant; no contaminated doses were ever released to the public.

headline: Johnson & Johnson investors reject proposal to end global talc sales.
snippet: The shareholder resolution, which had urged the company to pull talc-based baby powder from shelves around the world, stemmed from concerns about asbestos contamination.

headline: F.D.A. May Move Toward Updating Vaccines
snippet: Scientists had high hopes for a new coronavirus vaccine that combines the existing formulation with one targeting Omicron, but many are not impressed by the results.

headline: Lawmakers Dismiss McKinsey’s Apology on Opioid Crisis as ‘Empty’
snippet: The consulting firm’s top executive was apologetic before Congress but denied that advising both opioid manufacturers and their federal regulator posed a conflict of interest.

headline: These Companies Will Cover Travel Expenses for Employee Abortions
snippet: Dozens of companies have committed to helping their employees get access to reproductive care.

headline: Vaccines for Young Children Are Coming, but Many Parents Have Tough Questions
snippet: The vaccines seem safe for children and are likely to protect against severe illness. But data on efficacy is thin, and most children have already been infected.

headline: F.D.A. advisers recommend the authorization of Covid shots by Novavax, a latecomer in the vaccine race.
snippet: Clinical trials found the vaccine to work well, but the company has long struggled with manufacturing.

headline: The Drive to Vaccinate the World Against Covid Is Losing Steam
snippet: Rates are stalling in most low-income countries well short of the W.H.O.s goal to immunize 70 percent of people in every nation. Some public health experts believe the momentum is gone forever.

headline: The U.S. is extending a vaccine rule for international travelers at its land borders.
snippet: Unlike air travelers entering the United States, land and ferry travelers will still not have to show a recent negative coronavirus test to cross the border.
